rights_of_access.description: Any person of the age of majority may inspect, copy, or reproduce any public record. Louisiana's Public Records Act creates a presumption in favor of public access to government records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Requester must be age of majority (18 or older)
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Louisiana has one of the broadest public records laws in the nation. The presumption is strongly in favor of disclosure.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite La. R.S. 44:31: 'Any person of the age of majority may inspect, copy, or reproduce any public record.' The burden is on the agency to justify withholding.

rights_of_access.description: The custodian must respond to a request within three business days (excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays). If records are in active use, the custodian must certify this in writing and set a day and hour within three days for access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Three business days from receipt of request
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: The response requirement is to respond in some fashion, not necessarily to produce all records within three days. But the custodian must acknowledge the request and provide a timeline.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Track the three business day deadline. If no response, send follow-up: 'La. R.S. 44:32 requires a response within three business days. Please respond immediately with status of my request or a timeline for production.'

rights_of_access.description: There is no cost to inspect public records or make digital copies during regular working hours. Custodians cannot charge for inspection or for digital/electronic copies.
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Louisiana law explicitly states no cost for inspection or digital copies. Only paper copies may incur fees.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request records in digital format and cite La. R.S. 44:32: 'There shall be no cost to inspect or make digital copies of a public record during regular working hours.' Insist on free electronic delivery.

rights_of_access.description: State agencies must charge a uniform fee determined by the Commissioner of Administration. The recommended fee is 25 cents per page for standard-size copies and actual cost for other sizes.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to paper copies only; digital copies are free
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: The 25-cent fee is the standard, but always request digital copies first to avoid any fees.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide records in digital format at no cost per La. R.S. 44:32. If paper copies are necessary, the fee should not exceed 25 cents per page as recommended by the Commissioner of Administration.'

rights_of_access.description: The definition of 'public record' expressly includes electronically stored information and information contained in databases or electronic data processing equipment, regardless of physical form or characteristics.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to all electronic records and databases
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: The 2022 amendment ensures that agencies cannot claim electronic information is not a 'record.' Databases, emails, and all ESI are covered.
rights_of_access.request_tips: If an agency claims electronic data is not a record, cite the 2022 amendment to La. R.S. 44:1: 'Public records expressly include electronically stored information, regardless of physical form or characteristics.'

rights_of_access.subcategory: Electronic Means Preferred - No Additional Cost
rights_of_access.description: Records maintained on computer systems should be provided by electronic means where possible at no additional cost. Agencies cannot charge extra for electronic delivery.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies when records are maintained electronically
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Electronic delivery via email or download should be the default. Paper copies should only be used when electronic is not feasible.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide all responsive records electronically via email or download link at no cost, as required when records are maintained on computer systems per La. R.S. 44:32.'

rights_of_access.subcategory: Social Media and Private Accounts Are Public Records
rights_of_access.description: Public business communications conducted on private email accounts, devices, and social media platforms are public records. Text messages used in the performance of government work are also public records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Content must relate to government business, regardless of platform
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Louisiana courts have affirmed that the use of private platforms for public business does not shield records from disclosure. The content, not the platform, determines public record status.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Include in requests: 'Please search all platforms where government business is conducted, including private email accounts, text messages, and social media, as these are public records under La. R.S. 44:1 regardless of the platform used.'

rights_of_access.description: Custodians must provide reasonable estimates of completion time and offer answers to help requesters find the records they seek. Agencies have a duty to assist requesters.
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: If you're not sure exactly what to request, the custodian must help you identify the right records. They cannot simply deny a request for being too vague without offering assistance.
rights_of_access.request_tips: If an agency claims your request is unclear, respond: 'Under La. R.S. 44:32, the custodian must provide answers to help me find the records I seek. Please suggest how I should refine my request or describe what records you maintain related to [subject].'

rights_of_access.description: If records are in active use when requested, the custodian must promptly certify this in writing and fix a day and hour within three days for access. The requester is entitled to know when records will be available.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies when records are in active use
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Active use is a temporary condition. The custodian must commit to a specific time for access, not an indefinite delay.
rights_of_access.request_tips: If told records are in active use, request written certification per La. R.S. 44:32 specifying the exact day and hour within three business days when records will be available.

rights_of_access.description: Requesters are not required to state the purpose of their request or explain why they want records. Louisiana's Public Records Act is requester-blind.
rights_of_access.conditions: No conditions on requester identity or purpose
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies sometimes ask why you want records. This is not required and should not affect whether records are disclosed.
rights_of_access.request_tips: If asked for your purpose, respond: 'Louisiana law does not require me to state the purpose of my request. La. R.S. 44:31 grants the right to access records without regard to the requester's purpose.'

rights_of_access.description: Custodians must present public records 'promptly' upon request. While three days is allowed for a response, simple requests should be fulfilled immediately when records are readily available.
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: For routine requests (e.g., a specific document you can identify), agencies should not take the full three days. 'Promptly' means without unnecessary delay.
rights_of_access.request_tips: For simple requests, note: 'This is a routine request for readily available records. La. R.S. 44:32 requires prompt production. I expect these records to be available immediately or within hours, not the full three business days.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters have the right to inspect records before deciding which to copy or reproduce. This allows review of voluminous records to select only what is needed.
rights_of_access.conditions: Inspection allowed during regular business hours
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Inspection is especially valuable for large sets of records where you want to review first. Bringing a camera or phone to photograph during inspection may be permitted.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Include: 'I request the opportunity to inspect responsive records before copying. This will allow me to select only the records I need and minimize costs per La. R.S. 44:31.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters may seek judicial review through mandamus or other appropriate remedy when agencies improperly deny access. Courts can order production and may award attorney fees.
rights_of_access.conditions: Available when agency violates the Act
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Louisiana courts have consistently ruled in favor of broad access. Attorney fees are available to prevailing plaintiffs, making enforcement more accessible.
rights_of_access.request_tips: If denied, document everything. Louisiana courts favor disclosure. Consult an attorney about mandamus relief and potential fee recovery under La. R.S. 44:35.

rights_of_access.description: State agencies must use a uniform fee schedule determined by the Commissioner of Administration. Agencies cannot create their own fee structures or charge arbitrary amounts.
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: If an agency quotes fees that seem high or inconsistent, check the Commissioner's official fee schedule. Arbitrary fees violate the uniform requirement.
rights_of_access.request_tips: If fees seem excessive, ask: 'Please provide a breakdown showing compliance with the uniform fee schedule mandated by La. R.S. 44:32 and established by the Commissioner of Administration.'

rights_of_access.description: Information contained in databases or electronic data processing equipment is explicitly covered as public records. Requesters can access structured data, not just document outputs.
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies sometimes offer to provide printouts of database information when the actual structured data would be more useful. Request the underlying data.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide the responsive database records in structured format (CSV, Excel, or database export) rather than printouts. La. R.S. 44:1 includes information contained in databases as public records.'

National Freedom of Information Coalition - Louisiana Resources
validation_metadata.verification_notes: All rights verified against La. R.S. 44:1 et seq. as of October 2025. Louisiana amended the definition of public records in 2022 to explicitly include electronically stored information. No cost for inspection or digital copies is a unique strength of Louisiana law.
